item.description:
GUNG HEI FAT CHOY!

It's the Year of the Black Water Snake!

February 10th is the start of the Lunar New Year and the celebration lasts for two weeks.

Boston's Chinatown holds festivities on February 17th.

Join the OnyxBirds on our exploration into what is considered the most important festival in Chinese culture

Bring cash, a camera and your sense of adventure as well as wear comfortable footwear and warm clothes.

Along the street, vendors will be selling food and trinkets..

Catch up with us when you can at any of the locations and times

ACTIVITY OPTIONS:

10:45 AM- We'll meet at Sovereign Bank (61 Harrison Ave 02111) then we'll move closer to Philips Square, which is half a block away on Harrison Avenue between Beach and Essex Streets. The Lion Dance Parade steps off the Chinese New Year Celebration at 11 AM. This is a lively, loud and colorful spectacle of dance troupes performing individually, ritualistic dance movements in elaborate lion costumes, accompanied by clanging cymbals. The lions make their way through the streets stopping at businesses which entice them with oranges (represents wealth) and lettuce (represents health) as well as firecrackers. The lions visit ensures a prosperous year.

At 11:25 AM we'll make our way through the crowd to Hei La Moon for dim sum, a very affordable and delicious dining experience. It's family dining which means sharing. We select food from carts that are wheeled to our table. The price range for each person is from $10 to $15. You can also order separately from a menu...safe but not as adventurous. Check out this helpful dim sum primer written by Pam Phillips, a fellow meetup member.

A traditional Chinese New Year menu features a la carte dishes such as xiao long bao (traditional dumplings with broth inside); long life noodles with char siu pork, and hot-and-sour whole crispy fish.

After dim sum about 2 PM we can burn off a few calories:

1) Walking around Chinatown taking in more of the celebration and eating pastries from shops along the way.

2) Explore other aspects of Chinese tradition in The Cultural Village, which is hosted by East West Bank at 68 Harrison Avenue from noon until 5 PM. There will be live music and tables for dough sculpture, pinwheel making, calligraphy, painting, and a kiosk to have a picture taken with the head from a lion dance costume.

3) Ice skating on the Frog Pond in the Boston Common. Cost: $5 for Admission $9 for Rentals $2 for Locker.

4) Check out a movie at AMC Loews - Boston Commons 19 movie schedule (175 Tremont Street)

If you you need more details, have suggestions or need to find us that day, you may call or text me on my cell 617 445-7549 or email me at snowrover@yahoo.com

Before I list the Reservation Rules, please understand the NO-SHOW policy was established to ensure everyone who wants to join can and it will be fairly and strictly enforced. I want to assure you I do understand if you've RSVPd YES and you have a sudden change of plans because you don't feel well, you have transportation issues and not because you got a better offer. My only request is for you to let me know as soon as possible so we don't worry about you and our reservation is adjusted. As long as you contact me you will not be considered a NO-SHOW.

Rules for Events with Reservations:

If it is less than an 24 hours from the meal and you are not able to attend or are running late, you MUST call or text me at (617) 445-7549.

Please be considerate of your fellow diners time by arriving promptly.

Please bring enough cash to pay for your meal, drinks, tip, and tax.

All RSVPs are on a first reply, first seated basis.

You may only RSVP YES or NO. Maybe isn't an option.

Please RSVP YES only if you are certain you will attend.

If you're not sure you can attend because you have other unconfirmed plans or uncertain transportation, please RSVP NO with a comment.

If the meal is full and you wish to attend, please select WAIT LIST RSVP. When a spot opens, your RSVP will be changed to YES based on the time of your WAIT LIST RSVP and if you answered the RSVP question.

If your name appears on the event page as a YES after the meal and you have not attended nor contacted me, it is counted as a NO-SHOW.

If I change your RSVP to NO because you haven't replied to final update meal confirmation email deadline, it is counted as a NO-SHOW.

If any guests you've RSVPd for NO-SHOW each will count as if you've NO-SHOWED.

If you change your RSVP from a YES to a NO within 24 hours of the reservation, it is counted as a NO-SHOW if you do not contact me.

If you are a NO-SHOW for three events with reservations you are removed from the group.

NO-SHOWS impact everyone; from you, who could or has been on the wait list to the organizer as well as the restaurant's who staff based on our reservation.

An email from you explaining your absence is an expected courtesy.

If you are removed and there were extenuating circumstances, please email Tonya about rejoining.

Your feedback is appreciated so please, rate the event and venue by completing surveys afterward.
item.how_to_find_us: Call/text my cell (617) 445 7549 or email snowrover@yahoo.com to find us.

group.name: Breakfast, Brunch, Lunch, & Dinner Meetup Group

item.name: Chinese New Year Celebration and Dim Sum
